description.narrative: The DARDC comprises a joint investment by the Gov of TL and the WB to upgrade and strengthen the climate resilience of the road infrastructure linking Dili to the capitals of Aileu and Ainaro Districts.

activity-description.narrative: knowledge and understanding of local drivers of climate induced disasters enhanced, and consequent impacts on economic infrastructure better understood and available to policy makers, planners and technical staff

knowledge and understanding of local drivers of climate induced disasters enhanced, and consequent impacts on economic infrastructure better understood and available to policy makers, planners and technical staff

knowledge and understanding of local drivers of climateinduced disasters enhanced, and consequent impacts on economic infrastructure better understood and available to policy makers, planners and technical staff

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1. No. of target institutions with increased capacity for climate and disaster risk management, planning, budgeting and delivery at the national and sub-national level. 2. No. of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to reduce risks of and response to climate variability. 3. No. of staff trained on technical CCA and DRM themes, disaggregated by gender. 4. Type and no. of recommendations to sector policies, strategies, and plans for climate change adaptation and DRM that specifically address needs of women. 5. Increase in amount of funds delivered on climate risk reduction measures at the sub-national/district level. 6. % of women benefited from community-level climate risk reduction measures. 7. Risk reduction and awareness activities introduced at local level, including: (i) EWS; (ii) improved resilience of agriculture systems; (iii) Erosion control/sustainable land and water management. 8. No. of households engaged in climate resilient land use methods and livelihoods disaggregated by gender. 9. Coverage of land with changed land use conducive to landscape stability, protecting livelihoods and physical infrastructures against climate hazards risk and disasters. 10. % of households that demonstrate an awareness between improved land use and food security/disaster mitigation through their livelihoods-disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative: 1. Capacity for climate and disaster risk planning, budgeting and delivery at the national and sub-national level is limited 2. MSS, NDMD, DDMCs and other institutions have limited capacity to reduce risks and respond to climate variability. 3. Few staffs and community leaders have received comprehensive technical training on CCA and DRM themes. 4. Sector policies strategies and plans do not explicitly include climate change adaptation and DRM, and do not specifically address the needs of women concerning climate change and DRM. 5. Few measures for community-level disaster mitigation are currently implemented through DDMCs/district disaster focal points. 6. Women are rarely direct beneficiaries of measures for community-level disaster prevention and preparedness. 7. Few households currently benefit from risk reduction and awareness activities. 8. Few households have access to resilient livelihoods and methods 9. No Early Warning Systems (EWS) are currently in place. 10. No watershed management plans do exist. 11. Currently land left behind in shifting, slash-and-burn agriculture are left to recover without intervention and are a major source of vulnerability for communities and the road. 12. Current understanding of the links between land use and livelihoods, food and nutrition security and disasters is low.

1. MSS, NDMD, DDMCs have capacity for climate and disaster risk management planning, budgeting and delivery at the national and sub-national (at least Level 4: Widespread, but not comprehensive, evidence of capacity) 2. MSS, NDMD, DDMCs, MAF and other institutions have increased adaptive capacity to reduce risks and respond to climate variability 3. 200 staff and community leaders have receive technical training on CCA and DRM themes with at least 50% women benefiting 4. Recommendations for at least 3 sector policies, strategies and plans that explicitly include climate change adaptation and DRM. 5. Recommendations for at least 3 sector policies, strategies and plans specifically address the needs of women concerning climate change adaptation and DRM. 6. Full expenditure of additional funds ($50,000 per district per annum) on measures for community-level climate risk reduction implemented through DDMCs/district disaster focal points 7. 50% of beneficiaries of community-level measures for climate related disaster risk reduction and preparedness are women 8. At least 5,000 households will benefit from risk reduction activities and awareness activities comprising: a. EWS b. Improved resilience of agricultural systems c. Erosion control/sustainable land and water management 9. Score improved to 4: By the end of the project, at least 50% of targeted households have engaged in climate resilient land use methods and livelihoods introduced/strengthened in the project. 10. at least a quarter of targeted area of degraded lands reforested or other land stabilization methods applied (e.g. agroforestry, fodder and timber production etc.) while decreasing vulnerability of the DARDC to disasters 11. At least 50% of households surveyed confirm a clear link between resource management and resilience of livelihoods and physical infrastructure assets

1. Developed and launched CBDRM manuals 2. Total of 243 community members form 7 Administrative Post (laulara, Aileu, Liquideo, remexio, Alas, Same, Fatuberlio) received trainings on CBDRM and eraly response . 3. National Disaster Loss and Damage database (http://tldd.mss.gov.tl) has been developed to support DRM institutions for DRR planning and implementation. 4. National DRM policy revised integrating Sendai Framework for DRR. The policy has been handed over to both Secretary of State of Civil Protection (SSCP) and MSS for submission to Council of Ministers for final approval. The policy has also been translated into Tetun as requested by the SSCP. 5. National Bamboo Development Strategy was launched in 2019 to promote sustainable bamboo value chain system in Timor Leste and increased the production capacity of Bamboo Institute. 6 bamboo groups in 3 municipalities (Aileu, Ainaro, Ermera) were supported in 2019 for bamboo plantation and duction capacity and bamboo groups to establish pre-processing centers. 6. 49 community groups (Directly benefits more than more than 148 community members) were directly supported by the project community grants provided through the top-up grants mechanism administered by the Ministry of State Administrtaion (MSA) thorugh livelihood activities such as activities such as agroforestry, paultry farming, horticultural, fish farming. 7. Developed an initial protocol for EWS focusing in four target municipalities i.e. Aileu, Ainaro, Ermera and Manufahi. The project has procured and installed 6 sets of automatic stations, 2 sets of extensometers for landslides monitoring and 2 sets of flood monitoring equipment. 8. Project implemented numerous watershed management activities including more than 160 ha agroforestry and reforestation, 470 check dams to control flood, water harvesting ponds etc. maintain
